author: .vbuterin
content:
> Is there anywhere discussing switching to binary tree and how if we went with ReGenesis?
<@!278762485497069569> I imagine switching to binary trees would still be mandatory; regenesis is just a word for *partially* stateless ethereum, so you'd still need witnesses for the parts of the state that are not stored by clients

author: .vbuterin
content: and those witnesses are currently needlessly 4x larger than required

author: .vbuterin
content: There's also lots of other good reasons to optimize for blocks having reasonable fully-stateless witness sizes even if average clients are not fully stateless: (i) small fraud proofs, (ii) ability to verify block correctness in arbitrary order, including latest-to-earliest, (iii) eth2 multi-shard friendliness

author: Deleted User
content: I totally agree on the benefits of switching to binary tree. My thoughts are mostly about the ways to achieve it operationally. There are various ways of getting there

author: vorot93
content: As a client developer I would appreciate two-tiered implementation spec: minimum compliance spec and optimum performance spec

author: vorot93
content: This way we could arrange a quick port to regenesis with a later view to make an optimized implementation
